sec.title: Background
sec.p: Anxiety and chronic pain are common comorbidities in patients with Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD), which are frequently managed with benzodiazepines (BZD) and opioids, respectively.

sec.title: Objective
sec.p: The purpose of this study was to determine if different combinations of opioids, benzodiazepines, and their substitutes – gabapentinoids (GABA) and selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors/serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SSRI/SNRI)– are associated with lower risk of acute respiratory events in COPD patients with co-occurring chronic pain and anxiety.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: This retrospective cohort study used a nationally representative sample of Medicare beneficiaries with COPD, chronic pain, and anxiety. Patients were grouped based on drug combination (opioid + BZD/Z-hypnotics, opioid + GABA, opioid + SSRI/SNRI, BZD/Z-hypnotics + GABA, BZD/Z-hypnotics + SSRI/SNRI, GABA + SSRI/SNRI, or ≥3 drugs). The primary outcome was emergency room (ER) visit or hospitalization due to acute respiratory events assessed up to 180 days following initiation of drug combination. Overdose secondary to central nervous system (CNS)-related drugs was also assessed up to 180 days following initiation of drug combination.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The drug combination opioid + GABA was associated with decreased risk for ER visit (HR 0.73 95% CI 0.61–0.87) and hospitalization (HR 0.69 95% CI 0.55–0.85). Opioid + SSRI/SNRI also showed decreased risk for ER visit (HR 0.84 95% CI 0.71–0.99). There was no significant difference in risk for CNS-related drug overdose among different drug combinations compared to opioid + BZD/Z-hypnotics.

sec.title: Conclusion and Relevance
sec.p: Opioids in combinations with GABA and SSRI/SNRI demonstrate relatively lower risk for acute respiratory events among patients with COPD and comorbid chronic pain and anxiety. The findings emphasize the need for multimodal management in this vulnerable population.
